categories.title: Hyperfy Development: Technical Enhancements, Asset Optimization, and Platform Expansion

content.text: Recent discussions in the Hyperfy community have centered around technical improvements, asset optimization workflows, inter-app communication, and expanding platform capabilities. Key areas of focus include object snapping, material linking, agentic workflows, mobile and voice support, and marketplace asset bundling.

In development discussions, object snapping was identified as a guide-only system without parent-child relationships. Workarounds using triggers and collider tags were proposed but may impact performance. Material linking issues were also addressed—developers must set mesh.linked = false to ensure unique materials per instance, and apply textureX/Y updates within app.on('update') for proper rendering.

Inter-app communication remains a challenge, with inconsistencies noted between world.get/set, app.send, and app.emit. The app.children array now supports full node traversal, and documentation improvements were requested to clarify integration patterns. Agentic workflows were proposed to validate scripts and support self-improving systems, signaling a future direction for Hyperfy tooling.

In the arena combat system, features like mob respawning, lock-on targeting, and AI avoidance were implemented and tested. Community members suggested enhancements such as sword range indicators, dodge mechanics, and fireball casting. Mobile editor support was also discussed, with Monaco editor working on Android but lacking functionality on iOS.

Voice and communication infrastructure were explored for AI assistant integration. LiveKit was recommended as a Twilio alternative for voice and SIP support, with FlowiseAI suggested for SMS handling. These tools are being considered for integration into Hyperfy v2, which is currently in Early Access and lacks voice, screen share, and video features.

Community members emphasized the need for a simplified, drag-and-drop interface for non-coders in Hyperfy v2. Documentation updates were requested to clarify the platform’s beta status and onboarding process. Security concerns were also raised, with suggestions to block links from non-$HYPER users to prevent phishing.

Asset optimization for the Hyperfy marketplace was another major topic. Developers discussed bundling multiple GLB files into a single .hyp file using scripts and parent objects. Voxvienne shared a workflow using Kenney base textures and emission-controlled edges to create performant 3D maps with only two draw calls and 500KB file sizes. Plans to add snappoints for modular building were also mentioned.

Support for 2D-style games using sprites and camera effects was discussed, indicating Hyperfy’s flexibility beyond traditional 3D environments. A native collections feature was requested to simplify asset bundling and sales on the marketplace.

categories.title: Hyperfy Development and AI Integration: Technical Discussions and Roadmap

content.text: The Hyperfy community has been actively discussing a range of technical topics, including object snapping, material linking, inter-app communication, and agentic workflows. Object snapping currently lacks parent-child relationships, with triggers and collider tagging proposed as a workaround. Material linking issues were addressed by setting mesh.linked = false to ensure material uniqueness, and texture updates require placement inside app.on('update') for proper rendering.

Inter-app communication remains a work in progress, with inconsistencies noted between world.get/set, app.send, and app.emit. The app.children array now supports full node traversal. Agentic workflows were proposed to validate scripts and improve feedback cycles, and a combat arena system with respawn logic and AI behavior was successfully tested. Mobile editor support is limited, especially on iOS, prompting requests for improved autocomplete and clipboard functionality.

The Modular Context Protocol (MCP) was introduced as a standardized API layer for AI agent interoperability. MCP simplifies integration with services like OpenAI and Anthropic by abstracting request/response formatting and enabling access to non-API resources such as databases and file systems. This reduces token usage and improves agent context. While similar functionality could be built manually, MCP’s standardization and speed of deployment were seen as key advantages.

Participants compared MCP to OpenRouter, noting that while OpenRouter selects optimal APIs, MCP unifies multiple services under a single interface. Concerns about vendor lock-in were raised, but the consensus was that MCP is foundational for future AI ecosystems. Feature requests included agent feedback cycles, lightweight modes, and clearer documentation on MCP’s benefits and integration with non-API resources.

Discussions also covered AI voice assistant infrastructure. bitpixi explored building a phone receptionist using ElevenLabs voice and a non-Twilio backend. LiveKit was recommended for voice and video integration, with FlowiseAI suggested for SMS handling. LiveKit is also planned for integration into Hyperfy v2. Security concerns were raised, including a request to block links from non-$HYPER users to prevent phishing.

Hyperfy v2 is in Early Access and lacks features like voice and screen sharing. Users requested a drag-and-drop interface for non-coders and better onboarding for deployment tools like Gemini 2.5 and Cursor. Feature suggestions included emote animation speed control, reflect mechanics for combat, and a no-code interface.

Asset optimization and bundling were also discussed. themattempire asked about combining 40+ GLBs into a single .hyp file. .somethingmoreprofessional suggested using a script and parent object. Voxvienne shared a Blender workflow using Kenney textures and emission edges to create maps with only two draw calls and 500KB file size. Plans to add snappoints for modular building were also mentioned.

There is growing interest in supporting 2D-style games within Hyperfy using sprites and camera effects. A native collections feature was requested to group assets for marketplace listings, and documentation needs were identified for asset bundling, Blender optimization, and emission techniques.
